metadata.case_name: Income Tax Officer v. M/s Mugneeram Bangur & Co. Land Department, Calcutta

facts.text: The respondent, M/s Mugneeram Bangur & Co. Land Department, Calcutta (vendors), were a firm carrying on the business of land development in Calcutta.

By an agreement dated July 7, 1948, the partners of the firm agreed to sell all the business of the said firm to the Amalgamated Development Limited (vendee), which company was promoted by the partners of the firm.
The agreement provided for sale of the entire business with effect from July 8, 1948, together with goodwill, stock in trade, fixtures, etc., and benefits of contracts.
Purchase price of Rs. 34,99,300 paid and satisfied by allotment of 17,500 Redeemable Preference shares of Rs. 100 each and 17,493 Ordinary shares of Rs. 100 each to vendors or nominees.
Company to undertake all debts and liabilities except income-tax, super-tax etc. on profits.
Schedule to agreement valued assets: Land Rs. 12,68,628-7-7, Goodwill Rs. 2,50,000, Motor Car Lorries Rs. 25,866-8-6, etc., total Rs. 36,21,029-0-9 less liabilities Rs. 1,21,729-0-9 = Rs. 34,99,300.
Income Tax Officer held Rs. 2,50,000 as surplus on sale of lands (stock in trade), not goodwill.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal held Rs. 2,50,000 as value of goodwill; transfer of going concern, capital gain, not taxable. Relied on Doughty v. Commissioner of Taxes.
Income Tax Officer appealed to Appellate Tribunal.

Tribunal held sale of going concern but Rs. 2,50,000 was excess value of lands (stock); however dismissed appeal as transaction mere adjustment between related entities (firm to company promoted by partners), entire share capital except 7 shares taken by vendor firm.

High Court in reference under s.66 Income Tax Act answered questions: No profit taxable; Rs. 2,50,000 represented surplus on lands; but no taxable profit due to nature of transaction. Question 1 given up.
Vendors engaged in buying land, developing it (roads, drains, electricity, school) and selling.
Tribunal noted Mugneeram Bangur Co. Land Department separate firm from Mugneeram Bangur Co., conveyances in name of latter, little value to name/goodwill.

legal_issues.text: Whether Income-tax Officer, Central Circle XIV, Calcutta, was competent to file the appeal before the Tribunal against the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
Whether the sum of Rs. 2,50,000 represented surplus on sale of lands (stock in trade) or value of goodwill.
Whether by sale of whole business there was taxable profit of Rs. 2,50,000.
Whether, in view of Tribunal findings that entire share capital of vendee except seven shares taken by vendor firm, there was taxable profit of Rs. 2,50,000.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rs. 2,50,000 was actually charged as lump sum profit on sale of stock in trade (lands), not goodwill.
Schedule specifies values, Rs. 2,50,000 shown as goodwill but really excess value of land.
Business of purely buying and selling land; even in slump sale, profit on stock traceable per Doughty's case.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Doughty v. Commissioner of Taxes (1927 A.C. 327)

petitioner_arguments.text: Vendors and vendee different entities (firm vs. company); cannot lift corporate veil.

respondent_arguments.text: Sale of business as going concern; slump transaction, no separate profit on stock.
If question 3 answered in favour, no need for others.

court_reasoning.text: Sale was of business as going concern per agreement and Tribunal; Doughty's case applies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Slump transaction; no separate sale or valuation of stock.

court_reasoning.text: Vendors not purely buying/selling; involved development (roads, drains, etc.), distinguishable from realization sale.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Difficult to attribute slump price to land cost.

court_reasoning.text: Schedule shows book cost of land, not market value on sale date; no effort to value land as transfer to own company.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even adding Rs. 2,50,000 to land not market value.

court_reasoning.text: No part of slump price attributable to stock-in-trade; per CIT Kerala v. West Coast Chemicals and Doughty's case, no taxable profit.

holdings.text: Question No. 3 answered in the negative: No taxable profit on sale of whole business.

precedents_cited.relevance: Slump sale of going concern; no taxable profit on stock if no separate valuation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Kerala v. West Coast Chemicals and Industries Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Where slump price paid and no portion attributable to stock-in-trade, no taxable profit.
High Court distinguished; outsiders holding shares (e.g., 400/6000 to sons) no difference.

statutes_cited.name: Income Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference to High Court by Tribunal.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court answered question No. 3 in the negative in favour of the vendors (assessee), holding no taxable profit arose from the slump sale of the going concern; no need to answer other questions.

key_quotes.text: "the sale of a whole concern which can be shown to be a sale at a profit as compared with the price given for the business, or at which it stands in the books does not give rise to a profit taxable to income-tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Doughty's case, core principle applied.

key_quotes.text: "the essence of the matter... is not that an extra amount has been gained... but whether it can fairly be said that there was a trading from which alone profits can arise in business."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains when slump sale profit taxable.

key_quotes.text: "In our view the sale was the sale of the whole concern and no part of the slump price is attributable to the cost of land."
key_quotes.speaker: court
